and Harriman) and Chomsky and Goodell who
support November 15.
Student Association President Jim Archibald

September. Gordon mentioned it to Rodriguez

The problem of merging the two student bodies, however, seemed simple
when placed next to the task of uniting
the two faculties. It was the fears of the
faculty which prevented the merger plans
from ever becoming reality and which
dictated that this school accept its own
coeds if it wanted women undergraduates.
Faculty objections to a Goucher-Hopkins merger can be grouped into three
general categories: political, academic
and professional. The faculty wields all
of the political power at Hopkins presently. The unit of government is the
department, and as any Hopkins administrator will mournfully tell you, the
departments here do precisely what they
want (assuming that the funds are there).
A union of the faculties of the two
schools would wreak havoc with this
strict adherence to the departmental
system as it now exists. Consider that
Goucher has a faculty in American Studies. Would that department be subsumed
under one of Hopkins departments? English? History? Humanities? Or would it
be allowed to survive the merge? The
last possibility strikes the most terror
into the hearts of the faculty.If a department (comprised only of Goucher professors) were admitted into the Hopkins
faculty and given equal status with the
established departments
the faculty
would consider its autonomy, authority
and importance threatened.
The difference and conflicts in departmental structure points out the
second category into which arguments
against merging fell. This is the area of
academic concerns. Professors
at
Goucher and Hopkins do not always see
eye on exactly how their subjects are to
be taught. The Hopkins faculty knew that
this would cause problems. Take, for
example, the Psychology Departments
of the two schools.Goucher's department
is concerned with psychological theory

to a much greater extent than is that of
Hopkins. On paper, it looks as though
the fact that the two departments differ
would make for one well-rounded department upon consolidation. However, this
could not occur.
Hopkins' departments are small.They
tend
to specialize in a particular
academic or methodological area. If it
is (as in the case of Psychology) behaviorist, there is very little room or
welcome for a psychologist whose acaw elcome for a psychologist whose
academic views differ.Similar situations
would no doubt occur when dealing with
the History departments, Biology departments, etc.
In many cases, the fact that the members of the departments disagree over
academic matters leads them to downgrade the worth of the other department entirely. Thus, we come to the third
reason for faculty resistance to a Hopkins-Goucher merge. Last year, when
rumors that an agreement was imminent
were flying, several faculty members
contended that the move was unwise because appending Goucher professors onto
the Hopkins faculty would lower the standards of tl- faculty.
This is simply a matter of academic
prestige. The argument most frequently
heard is that without a union of the two
schools, few of the Goucher faculty would
be asked to join the ranks of Hopkins professors. The research done by Goucher
professors (it is claimed) is not up to
Hopkins' high standards. It is a fact that
the faculty at Goucher is much more
oriented toward teaching than is the Hopkins faculty. Correspondingly,the amount
of time devoted and the importance attached to research is not as great. This
may well account for the attitude of the
Hopkins faculty.
These political, academic and professional objections convinced the faculty
that a merger was inadvisable. They
certainly would have made it unfeasible.

By admitting its own women undergraduates, however, Hopkins has lost certain
advantages which a merger woilld have
provided.
First, in areas where Goucher is
clearly superior, Hopkins could have
benefited greatly from the union. The
case of the language departments is most
obvious. Goucher is superior in most of
the languages and dwarfs Hopkins in
areas such as Slavic languages.
Second, Goucher has strong programs
in areas which Hopkins completely
ignores. The performing and fine arts
are of interest to many Hopkins students,
but they find nothing at their own school.
Hence, we find more than thirty Hopkins
undergraduates enrolled in courses at
Goucher.
If sufficient energy and funds were
diverted into the language departments
at Hopkins, they could rival and surpass
those of Goucher. However, Hopkins will
not develop any kind of fine arts program in the near future.
Again, this is due to the reaction of
the faculty. It is a cardinal rule at Hopkins that if a Ph.D cannot be granted in
the subject, it ought not to be taught.
The fine arts and the performing arts
are areas of increasing interest among
Hopkins students, but by their "semiacademic" nature, they are excluded
from Hopkins curriculum.
If a Hopkins student wants to take
courses in the fine arts, he must take
them at another school. Goucher provides the necessary courses. In other
areas where Goucher provide‘: opportunities not found at Hopkins, there will
also be an increasing number of enrollees
from Hopkins (in languages, perhaps).
Although the recommendations of the
Academic Council preclude any possibility of a merger with Goucher, look
for increasing cooperation between the
two schools. Hopkins will find that when
it has enrolled its own women, it will
need the assistance of the College much
more than it does presently.

IS "LOTTERY" DOOMED?
By RICK FITCH (CPS)
As prospects diminish that both legislative branches will pass the administration's lottery draft proposal by the end
of this year, chances increase that President Nixonwill enact by executive order
a "conveyor belt" system of induction
in early 1970.
Under this form of conscription, 19year-olds would be made the "prime
age group" for draft calls with their
liability to the draft limited to one year.
Age would determine the order of induction. A person whose 19th birthday
fell during January would be called up
before a person with a February birthday.
Since it discriminates against those
with birthdays early in the year(persons
born in October, November or December might never by subject to the draft),
the conveyor belt would be less equitable than a lottery, under which one of the
year's 365 days would be picked at random and all 19-year-olds born on that
date made draftable.
Both approaches to procuring military manpower would reduce a person's
draft vulnerability from seven years to
one, making him draft free at age 20,
both would defer college students. plac-

ing them in the pool of draftables for
one year after graduation,and both would
defer graduate students until they have
completed the full academic year.
But the lottery, unlike the conveyor
belt, can't bestablished without congressional approval. Both the Senate and
House have to vote to change a provision
in the 1967 Selective Service Act prohibiting random selection of draftees.
And everyone, from Sen. Edward Kennedy (D-Mass.), a leading proponent of
draft reform, to Sen. John Stennis (DMiss.) chairman of the Senate Armed
Services Committee, is predicting this
won't occur until Congress reconvenes
next year.
The reason is that many legislators,
desiring more sweeping Selective Service reforms, are unwilling to go along
with the administration and its congressional leadership in speedily passing the
lottery without considering amendments.
In a press conference sponsored by
the National Council to Repeal the Draft,
Reps. Shirley Chisholm, Edward Koch
and Leonard Farbstein, all New York
Democrats, criticized the lottery proposal as too minor a reform. They called
for total abolition of military conscription.

concerning Columbia, Harvard and Cornell arise.

As prospects diminish that both legislative branches will pass the administration's lottery draft proposal by the end
of this year, chances increase that President Nixonwill enact by executive order
a "conveyor belt" system of induction
in early 1970.
Under this form of conscription, 19year-olds would be made the "prime
age group" for draft calls with their
liability to the draft limited to one year.
Age would determine the order of induction. A person whose 19th birthday
fell during January would be called up
before a person with a February birthday.
Since it discriminates against those
with birthdays early in the year(persons
born in October, November or December might never by subject to the draft),
the conveyor belt would be less equitable than a lottery, under which one of the
year's 365 days would be picked at random and all 19-year-olds born on that
date made draftable.
Both approaches to procuring military manpower would reduce a person's
draft vulnerability from seven years to
one, making him draft free at age 20,
both would defer college students. plac-

ing them in the pool of draftables for
one year after graduation,and both would
defer graduate students until they have
completed the full academic year.

belt, can't bestablished without congressional approval. Both the Senate and

in the 1967 Selective Service Act prohibiting random selection of draftees.

draft reform, to Sen. John Stennis (DMiss.) chairman of the Senate Armed
Services Committee, is predicting this
won't occur until Congress reconvenes
next year.

desiring more sweeping Selective Service reforms, are unwilling to go along

the National Council to Repeal the Draft,

Democrats, criticized the lottery proposal as too minor a reform. They called
for total abolition of military conscription.
